The idea that microorganisms play a role in disease was established by several scientists in the 19th century, including:

- Louis Pasteur (1822-1895) - A French chemist who demonstrated that fermentation and disease are caused by microorganisms. He developed the germ theory of disease and the process of pasteurization to kill microbes.

- Robert Koch (1843-1910) - A German physician who identified the bacteria that cause anthrax, tuberculosis, and cholera. He established Koch's postulates to demonstrate that a specific microbe causes a specific disease. 

- Joseph Lister (1827-1912) - A British surgeon who pioneered antiseptic surgery by using carbolic acid to kill microbes during surgery. This greatly reduced post-operative infections.

- John Snow (1813-1858) - An English physician who in 1854 traced a cholera outbreak in London to a contaminated public water pump, establishing that cholera was spread by microbes in contaminated water.

So in summary, the germ theory of disease stating that microorganisms are the cause of many diseases was established in the late 19th century thanks to the pioneering work of scientists like Pasteur, Koch, Lister and Snow through experiments, observations and epidemiological studies. Their work was pivotal in revolutionizing medicine.

The Wave Hill walk-off was an Indigenous Australian land rights protest movement that started in August 1966. It involved Aboriginal stockmen and their families walking off Wave Hill Station in the Northern Territory to protest poor pay and working conditions.

Some key facts about the Wave Hill walk-off:

- It began on August 23, 1966 when around 200 Aboriginal stockmen and their families left Wave Hill Station to camp at Wattie Creek. This was led by Vincent Lingiari.

- The protest was against the poor pay and conditions for Aboriginal workers on the British-owned cattle station, as well as the lack of recognition of Aboriginal land rights. 

- It continued for over 8 years, making it one of the longest strikes in Australian history. 

- In 1975, the Australian government granted the Gurindji people title to part of their traditional lands, marking a major win for Indigenous land rights. 

- On August 16, 1975, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam symbolically poured sand into Vincent Lingiari's hand to recognize the Gurindji land rights, in a ceremony at Wave Hill.

- In 1985, the Gurindji were granted additional land rights to more of their traditional lands with the passing of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.

Norman Borlaug is known as the father of the Green Revolution in India. Some key points about Norman Borlaug and the Green Revolution in India:

- Norman Borlaug was an American agronomist and humanitarian who developed high-yielding, disease resistant wheat varieties in Mexico in the 1940s-1960s. These varieties later spread to India and Pakistan.

- In the 1960s, Borlaug worked with Indian agronomists to import semi-dwarf, high-yielding wheat varieties into India and teach local farmers new agricultural techniques. This was the start of the Green Revolution in India.

- The new wheat varieties, combined with irrigation infrastructure, fertilizers and pesticides, led to dramatic increases in wheat yields per acre in India. This helped transform India from a country reliant on food aid to a net food exporter.

- Wheat yields in India nearly doubled between the mid-1960s and mid-1970s due to Borlaug's semi-dwarf varieties. This helped alleviate hunger and famine in the country.

- For his contributions to agriculture in Mexico, India and other countries, Norman Borlaug was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1970 for helping fight world hunger. He has since been called the "father of the Green Revolution."

So in summary, Norman Borlaug's work developing disease resistant, high-yielding wheat varieties and transferring the technology to India in the 1960s launched the Green Revolution

In 1863, Hunley built a small hand-powered submarine called the H. L. Hunley for the Confederate States of America. The Hunley was designed to attack and sink Union ships by stealth, ramming the enemy vessel with a spar torpedo.

This made the mission the first successful submarine attack in history, but also one of the first submarine disasters.

The 10 shilling note was a banknote issued by the Bank of England worth half of one pound sterling. It was issued from 1928 to 1970 when it was withdrawn from circulation. Some key details about the 10 shilling note:

- It was first issued in 1928, replacing the previous 10 shilling Treasury note. The original 1928 design featured a portrait of Britannia on the front.

- The note was changed in the early 1960s to feature a portrait of Florence Nightingale on the front. This updated "Series C" 10 shilling note began circulation in 1961.

- With the decimalization of British currency in 1971, the 10 shilling note was withdrawn from circulation. Decimal 10 pence coins replaced the 10 shilling note beginning in 1968 in the run up to full decimalization. 

- The last 10 shilling notes were removed from circulation by the early 1970s. Banks were instructed to withdraw any remaining notes by the end of 1970.

So in summary, the 10 shilling banknote enjoyed over 40 years in circulation from 1928 to the early 1970s, when it was demonetized and pulled from circulation due to the UK's transition to a full decimal currency system. The last notes were withdrawn by banks at the end of 1970.

There are a few theories about how this phrase became popular:

- It was influenced by the Darwinian theory of evolution, implying that humans evolving from apes/monkeys is as unbelievable as a monkey having an uncle.

- It refers to the fact that monkeys don't have familial relationships like "uncles" that humans do, so saying "monkey's uncle" is absurd.

- It's thought to be a variant of earlier phrases like "my aunt's cat" or "my grandmother's whiskers" - meaningless phrases used to express surprise. Replacing aunt/grandmother with "monkey" gave it an absurd, nonsensical edge.

- The phrase was popularized in the U.S. after being used in a comic strip called "Uncle Eben's Ignorance" where a character says "Well knock me down for a monkey's uncle!" in surprise.

So in summary, "monkey's uncle" became a humorous way to express disbelief or shock by invoking an absurd, nonsensical image that pokes fun at the idea of monkeys having human familial relationships. The silliness of the phrase conveys the feeling without having to state it directly.

If there is a tie vote in the United States Senate, there are a few ways it can be broken:

- The Vice President of the United States, who serves as President of the Senate, can cast a tie-breaking vote. This is the most common way ties are broken.

- Senators can agree to table or postpone the issue that resulted in a tie. This allows them more time to negotiate or bring in absent Senators to vote. 

- The Senate Majority Leader can make a motion to reconsider the vote at a later time when more Senators are present.

- For votes on procedural matters, the tie vote means the motion fails. The status quo is preserved. 

- On votes to confirm presidential nominations, a tie vote means the nomination fails. 

So in summary, the Vice President can break tie votes with their vote, but Senators have some procedural options as well if they want to revisit a tied vote later. The Vice President has cast over 250 tie-breaking votes since 1789, so it's a very common occurrence.

Canada switches to daylight saving time (DST) on the second Sunday in March each year. The time changes at 2:00 am local time, when clocks move forward by 1 hour to 3:00 am.

The dates for the next few years are:

- 2023: March 12 at 2:00 am (spring forward)
- 2024: March 10 at 2:00 am
- 2025: March 9 at 2:00 am 

Canada then switches back to standard time on the first Sunday in November each year, when clocks move back 1 hour from 2:00 am to 1:00 am local time. The fall back dates are:

- 2023: November 5 at 2:00 am 
- 2024: November 3 at 2:00 am
- 2025: November 2 at 2:00 am

So in summary, Canada observes DST from the second Sunday in March through the first Sunday in November each year, like most of the United States. The actual switch dates vary each year.

Here are a few key points about the term "ambulatory" in healthcare:

- It refers to patients who are able to walk/move around and do not need to be bedridden. Ambulatory patients are the opposite of non-ambulatory or bedridden patients.

- Ambulatory care refers to medical services provided on an outpatient basis, without admission to a hospital. This includes visits to a doctor's office, clinic, urgent care center, etc. Ambulatory care is less intensive than inpatient hospital care.

- An ambulatory surgery center is a healthcare facility that specializes in providing same-day surgical care, allowing patients to walk in and out without an overnight stay. Common procedures done at these centers include endoscopies, colonoscopies, cataract surgeries.

- Ambulatory devices are tools designed to assist patients with walking, such as canes, walkers, crutches, etc. These allow patients with injuries, disabilities or mobility issues to move around on their own without major assistance.

- Ambulatory monitoring refers to portable or wearable technology used to track a patient's vital signs or health data while they go about their daily activities. This may include ECG monitors, EEGs, glucose monitors, etc.

In summary, "ambulatory" implies that the patient can walk and move about to some degree, in contrast to bedbound patients who cannot independently move or walk. It is

The standard width of a cricket bat is 4.25 inches (108 mm).

Some key points about cricket bat widths:

- The Laws of Cricket specify that the width of the bat shall not exceed 4.25 inches at its widest part.

- Bats typically taper slightly from the middle to the handle and toe. But the entire hitting surface cannot exceed 4.25 inches.

- The edges of the bat should also not exceed 1.56 inches in thickness. 

- Bat widths have become more standardized in recent decades. In the past, bats with widths up to 4.75 inches were sometimes used.

- Wider bats provide a larger hitting surface but may be less maneuverable. Narrower bats allow for more control and strokeplay.

- Bat width is one factor players consider when selecting a bat for their size, technique and playing style. Other factors include bat length, weight, balance and materials.

So in summary, 4.25 inches is the maximum legal width for a cricket bat under the sport's rules. Most bats today adhere very closely to this standard width.

The 2017 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN).

ICAN is a coalition of non-governmental organizations that advocates for the total abolition of nuclear weapons. They were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize "for its work to draw attention to the catastrophic humanitarian consequences of any use of nuclear weapons and for its ground-breaking efforts to achieve a treaty-based prohibition of such weapons".

The Nobel committee highlighted ICAN's role in advocating for the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons that was adopted by 122 countries earlier in 2017. While the treaty has not yet been ratified by any nuclear-armed nations, the Nobel committee recognized ICAN's efforts to "stigmatize, prohibit and eliminate nuclear weapons" through the groundbreaking treaty.

So in summary, the 2017 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) for their work on nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation.

Here are some key points about where wind power is used most in the United States:

- Texas - By far the largest producer of wind power, with over 30,000 megawatts of installed capacity. West Texas has large wind farms due to strong winds, open land, and abundant transmission lines.

- California - The second largest producer of wind power with over 6,000 megawatts of capacity. Large wind farms exist in mountain passes and the Tehachapi region. 

- Iowa - The third largest wind power state with over 10,000 megawatts of capacity. Iowa has great wind resources and lots of windy open land.

- Oklahoma - Has over 7,000 megawatts of wind capacity, mostly in the western half of the state where wind resources are superb.

- Kansas - Has over 6,000 megawatts of wind power capacity, primarily in the high wind central and western portions of the state.

- Illinois, Minnesota, Colorado, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming also have significant wind power capacity of over 3,000 megawatts each. The Great Plains, mountain states, and coastal regions tend to be the windiest.

So in summary, wind power is concentrated most in the Central Plains (Texas, Iowa, Kansas) as well as California due to strong wind resources and availability of open land areas.

The First Battle of Ypres was fought from 19 October to 22 November 1914 during World War I. It marked the end of the Race to the Sea, as the opposing armies dug extensive trench systems to hold their positions. The battle took place around the Belgian city of Ypres in West Flanders.

The battle concluded on 22 November 1914 with Allied forces managing to hold onto Ypres and the surrounding territory while preventing a German breakthrough. Both sides suffered heavy casualties, with over 200,000 total killed, wounded or missing. The battle established the trench warfare that would characterize the Western Front for the rest of the war. Though inconclusive, the First Battle of Ypres is seen as a strategic victory for the Allies by halting the German advance.

The Battle of Badr took place in 624 CE in western Arabia. It was a key battle during the early days of Islam between the new Muslim community of Medina led by the Prophet Muhammad and the Quraish tribe of Mecca. Some key points about the Battle of Badr:

- It occurred on March 17, 624 CE near the town of Badr in what is now western Saudi Arabia. 

- The Muslims had 313-317 men while the Quraish had about 1,000 men, but the Muslims were victorious.

- It was the first major battle between the Muslims and non-Muslims and proved to be a turning point for the early Muslim community.

- Several important Quraish leaders were killed in the battle, weakening pagan opposition to Islam in Mecca.

- The victory solidified Prophet Muhammad's position as leader of the Muslims and marked the beginning of his power in Arabia.

- After the battle, many more tribes joined Muhammad and converted to Islam, strengthening the Muslims.

So in summary, the Battle of Badr in 624 CE was the first major military victory for the early Muslims against overwhelming odds and proved pivotal for the growth of early Islam under Prophet Muhammad. Its result had religious, political, and strategic significance.

- The last stretch of the Red River in Louisiana flows into the Mississippi River near Simmesport in the central part of the state.

Here are some key details about the Colts leaving Baltimore:

- The Colts were originally founded in Baltimore in 1953. They were owned by Carroll Rosenbloom.

- In 1972, Rosenbloom swapped ownership of the Colts with Robert Irsay, who owned the Los Angeles Rams at the time. This gave Irsay ownership of the Colts.

- Under Irsay's ownership, the Colts struggled both on the field and with attendance in the late 1970s. Irsay began making demands for a new stadium to replace Memorial Stadium in Baltimore. 

- When no agreement could be reached on a new stadium, Irsay began discussions with other cities about relocating the team. In the early morning hours of March 29, 1984, Irsay moved the Colts out of Baltimore to Indianapolis. 

- So in summary, Robert Irsay was the owner of the Colts when the team controversially left Baltimore for Indianapolis in 1984 after failing to reach a deal for a new stadium. Irsay's actions made him unpopular and vilified among Colts and Baltimore fans at the time.

- It was initially headed by Sachidanand Sinha as the interim president. He was succeeded by Rajendra Prasad as the permanent president.

- The Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution of India on 26 November 1949 and it came into effect on 26 January 1950.

- Rajendra Prasad later went on to become the first President of India in 1950 after the promulgation of the Constitution.

Here are some key details about the venom production of king cobras:

- King cobras can inject up to 7 ml of venom in a single bite. This is over 20 times more venom than most rattlesnake species.

- An adult king cobra can produce up to 500 mg of venom at a time. This is enough to kill 20 people or even an elephant.

- King cobras can produce new venom as quickly as every 6-7 days. So even after emptying all their stored venom in a bite, they can replenish it fairly quickly.

- The venom glands of a king cobra can hold up to 1-1.5 grams of venom at maximum capacity. However, they don't always store this much.

- Venom production depends on the snake's age, health, season, and frequency of use. Older, healthier snakes tend to produce more venom than younger ones.

- When threatened, king cobras can repeatedly strike and inject venom. The maximum number of bites in a short time period can be over 10-12 for an adult.

So in summary, an adult king cobra has the potential to inject over 10 ml of venom overall in multiple bites in self-defense. But the average amount of venom used per bite is much lower, around 2-7 ml. Their massive venom capacity makes them one of the most dangerous snakes in the world.

The brain gets most of its energy from glucose. Here are a few key points about how the brain gets energy:

- Glucose is the preferred fuel source for the brain. It gets glucose from the bloodstream.

- The brain cannot store glucose, so it requires a continuous supply from the blood to function properly. 

- The brain accounts for about 20% of the body's total energy needs, even though it only makes up about 2% of the body's weight.

- When blood glucose levels drop too low (hypoglycemia), brain function is impaired. That's why having regular food intake is important to maintain normal blood sugar levels.

- Besides glucose, the brain can also use ketone bodies for energy in certain situations like fasting or very low-carbohydrate diets. 

- Ketone bodies are derived from fat and can cross the blood-brain barrier to provide the brain with energy.

- The brain also requires oxygen to extract energy from glucose and ketone bodies through cellular respiration. So constant oxygen supply via breathing is essential for brain energy metabolism.

In summary, the predominant fuel source powering the high energy demands of the brain is glucose transported from the bloodstream. Ketone bodies can provide alternative energy in certain conditions.

preferred fuel source for the brain
continuous supply of glucose from the blood
20% of the body's total energy needs
high energy demands of the brain

The group that officially elects the president of the United States is called the Electoral College.

The Electoral College is the body of electors appointed by each state who formally elect the President and Vice President of the United States. When citizens vote for a presidential candidate during the general election, they are actually voting to instruct the electors from their state to vote for that candidate. 

The Electoral College consists of 538 electors. Each state gets a number of electors equal to its total number of Senators and Representatives in Congress. States with larger populations therefore have more electors. On election day, electors from each state gather in their state capitals to officially cast their votes for President and Vice President. Whichever candidate receives a majority of electoral votes (at least 270) wins the election.

So in summary, the Electoral College is the official constitutional mechanism for electing the President, with electors from each state representing the popular vote winners from their state. The candidate who reaches 270 or more electoral votes becomes the next President.
